commit.commit_title: fix: Fix Safari volume bug, #34797 (#34929)

prs.pr_title: fix: Fix Safari volume bug, #34797
prs.pr_body:
Fixes #34797

### Changes proposed in this PR:
- Fixes unresponsive volume control in Safari
- …which required a larger refactor than I hoped for. The issue was caused by a conflict between the main `Audio` component and the audio context created inside of `useAudioVisualizer`, which I cleaned up by creating a new `useAudioContext` hook and using that in the top-level component. That context is then passed into the visualizer hook.
  The context hook also returns a `gainNode` instance which reliably controls the volume in Safari.
- Moves the `resumeAudio` and `suspendAudio` into `useAudioContext` which returns unified `playAudio` and `pauseAudio` callbacks.

### Screencap

Note that the audio player currently looks broken in Safari and doesn't show the visualizer. This will be fixed in a follow-up PR

commit.commit_title: Replace local vars with `let` in JS-enabled system specs (#34905)

prs.pr_title: Replace local vars with `let` in JS-enabled system specs
prs.pr_body:
As part of https://github.com/mastodon/mastodon/pull/34867 I've had several hundred full E2E suite runs without failures. This is the one spec that did have a failure, and my guess is that the example filled in the field and sent `ctrl+enter` before the JS was ready to process that. So, this adds an assertion that some JS-rendered DOM portion is actually there, in hope to make it less likely for that to happen.

Also extracted local var to a `let`.

The playwright branch seems promising - going to continue doing partial suite runs there to see what other E2E stuff I can get to fail. Regular runs seem sufficiently more reliable there that I think finding failures might indicate actually async/load issues, rather than flaky runner/manager stuff.

commit.commit_title: Change “legacy” non-fast-tracked quote posts to not be displayed as such (#34945)

prs.pr_title: Change “legacy” non-fast-tracked quote posts to not be displayed as such
prs.pr_body:
Fixes #34943

This effectively downgrades compatibility with non-FEP-044f quote posts to only treat them as quote posts in the REST API if they are accepted.

In practice, this means fast-track (self-quotes or quotes from mentioned users) will be accepted and displayed as quote posts, other posts will just be whatever fallback the authoring software outputs.

This PR doesn't alter our compliance with FEP-044f, which mandates support for quote controls (since it's the point), but affects the fallback behavior with `quoteUri`, `quoteUrl`, and `_misskey_quote`, and may lead to confusion as to why some of those quote-posts work and some of them don't.

issues.issue_title: Better handling of quote containing post w/o support of FEP-044f
issues.issue_body:
### Pitch

Quotes containing post from platform without FEP-044f support (Misskey & forks, etc) just get stuck in limbo forever displaying "This post is pending approval from the original author." Just display the quoted post as-is or add explanation about it.

### Motivation

Seeing lots of quotes made from Misskey & forks displaying "This post is pending approval from the original author" message.

issues.issue_title: Expose ActivityStreams 2.0 representation of accounts
issues.issue_body:
This is the first step in ActivityPub integration. Clients may now request the user's account URL with an Accept header set to "application/activity+json" to get the AS2 representation. This JSON object will later point to a set of ActivityPub AS2 Collections (Outbox, Inbox, etc.).

I set up some RABL base templates for future use, to consolidate some properties (@context, id) and reduce boilerplate.

I used "image" for the header image, but I'm not sure that's the best approach. Would be nice to ensure clients have a way of getting a header image, and "image" seems like the only good option within AS2/AP.

Technically the endpoint should be able to respond to 'application/ld+json; profile="https://www.w3.org/ns/activitystreams#"' in the Accept header, but Rails seems to have trouble recognizing Mime + Profile types, so I stuck with "application/activity+json".

issues.issue_title: Bot user that boosts top toots -- to aid discoverability for users of new/small instances.
issues.issue_body:
Every instance should have an easy way to enable a standardized bot user to generate boosted toots of top toots. That way new/small sites can easily follow these top-toot-bots and get a good sample stream of content. The local users can then choose to follow some of the accounts that they see from the bots.

How should the bot choose? I'm not sure. Easiest choices are things like "25 starred/boosted toots", but what is the right number? 25? 10? 50? So maybe a better approach is "top starred/boosted toot of the past X minutes" ... but possibly harder to implement.

Without something like this, new/small instances are stuck in a chicken-and-egg situation.

issues.issue_title: Add "local" visibility for public messages addressed only to instance members (& change default visibility by "local")
issues.issue_body:
(Sorry my English level is too low)

Actuellement pour parler à de nouvelles personnes et faire de nouvelles rencontre, la visibilité "public" est très utile, mais elle ne permet pas de modérer cette visibilité à un publique plus restreint tel que les membres de l'instance.
Pourtant le fil "local" est très pratique pour les communautés, et la seule façon de communiquer entre membre est de publier des messages pour toutes les instances...

Avec cette visibilité "local" les membres d'une instance vont pouvoir communiquer entre eux sur le fil "local" sans noyer le fil "global".

De plus la visibilité par défaut est actuellement sur "global" et beaucoup d'utilisateurs ne changent pas ce paramètre est en viennent à partager par défaut leurs messages aux potentiels 200 000 utilisateurs des instances fédérés.
Le changement de ce paramètre par défaut sur "local" permet de modérer la visibilité des utilisateurs tout en nourrissant le fil "local" de leurs instances et en rendant le fil "global" moins dense.

issues.issue_title: redesign or revert web UI for mobile/small screens
issues.issue_body:
### Pitch

I know a lot of efforts have been devoted to changing the web UI layout, and i have seen #19263 about the reason for changing it, but to be honest, how mastodon looks on mobile phones now is really really weird. I dont hate changes, but what the new design is doing is cutting the screen horizontally once and then vertically once, and this ends up giving users a screen that is 15% smaller (i've calculated it) to scroll on and to look at stuff. How much time do people spend at clicking on buttons and how much time do people spend at looking at timelines? Obviously people dont need to see a full list of buttons all the time especially when it is at the expense of the amount and size of content you can look at on your screen.


Old | New
-- | --
![IMG_6641 copy](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/106132975/198928204-4bc0ee60-f306-4ab2-b2a0-8975164267d4.png) | ![IMG_6640 copy](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/106132975/198928164-e7150510-5697-4797-819b-431cf7800684.png)


### Motivation

I've also looked at the claimed impetus for the changes in #19487 (that thread isnt mainly on mobile UI design so i opened a new one)
>  Making better use of space on mobile devices

As i mentioned and calculated before, this obviously makes the effective space smaller. Every time i open mastodon.online/social on my phone i feel like scrolling on an iPhone mini emulator at the bottom left of my iPhone screen...

> making the look of the web app more consistent with our professionally designed native apps

I dont think the professionally designed apps have a vertical AND a horizontal crop. In fact I haven't seen any professionally designed mobile web UI doing such thing. The apps look fine to me but the mobile web UI layout looks nothing like the apps.

> cleaning up the mess of stylesheets that dealt with two different layouts across various responsive screen sizes.

I guess you do need to have different designs for different screens, because the screen of your laptop/PC has a landscape orientation and your mobile phone has a portrait one...It just makes no sense to use a same layout for everything, as screens do not only vary in sizes, they vary in orientations as well.


Hope people who spent a lot of time changing the mobile web UI layout wouldnt feel like their work has not been paid respect to, but i do think we could have a much much better web UI layout for mobile devices.

Thanks.

commit.commit_title: Start local prometheus_exporter server only in puma/sidekiq startup (#35005)

prs.pr_title: Start local prometheus_exporter server only in puma/sidekiq startup
prs.pr_body:
Fixes MAS-451

When `MASTODON_PROMETHEUS_EXPORTER_LOCAL` was set to `true` (e.g. through system-wide settings or in `.env.production`) the initializer would try to start a (new) local server. On systems running puma or sidekiq, the server would have been running already, so this would fail. This meant that on those systems one could not easily run a rails console, rails runner script or rails/rake task.

This change moves the server initialization to puma and sidekiq startup respectively.

This fixes the issue described above at the cost of a little flexibility (i.e. you cannot easily start a local prometheus exporter server outside of sidekiq/puma anymore, but I am not sure if this has been a real use-case to begin with).

Note that you still cannot use `MASTODON_PROMETHEUS_EXPORTER_LOCAL` when you run puma and sidekiq on the same machine, which includes dev environments starting the servers with the `bin/dev` script.

* Home timeline regeneration
* Fetch all replies
* Discovery FASP searches

We thought a lot about how to add hints for clients without breaking existing APIs. This is a sketch how this could look. In this solution, we add a new, custom HTTP header (`Mastodon-Async-Refresh`) that communicates that there is something running asynchronously that might warrant checking for new results later. A new, experimental API is added to query for the status of such "async refreshes".

~~I am mostly happy with this, except for the name: I think "BackgroundJob" makes it too easy to confuse this with sidekiq jobs or similar. This is *not* trying to re-implement sidekiq's job management and is *not* for every kind of background job.~~ (We renamed this to `AsyncRefresh`).

In this PR I also implemented this for home timeline regeneration, even though it is not strictly needed there (yet). Home timeline regeneration is a simple case, because we currently wait until it is fully finished. There is no number of new results to keep track of. As such there is still a bit missing that the other use-cases will need: Querying the endpoint again while sending along the original async refresh id.

I would have loved to implement a second use-case to include this missing bit as well, but also because I think some of this code can be made more generic, the Redis handling can be encapsulated better and so on. But I would prefer to refactor this according to actual use-cases instead of taking guesses. Sadly there was no time for that, so this will have to wait a bit.

issues.issue_title: Status wrappers have redundant `tabindex` attributes
issues.issue_body:
### Steps to reproduce the problem

1. Navigate to a toot by <kbd>Tab</kbd> on a keyboard
2. The whole toot is focusable (`.status__wrapper`/`.detailed-status__wrapper`)
3. Use <kbd>Tab</kbd> until you reach the content element itself (`.status__content`)


### Expected behaviour

Only the whole toot should be focusable (since clicking on it will result in an action)

### Actual behaviour

The content itself is focusable as well

### Detailed description

From my point of view, `.status__content` does not need `tabindex="0"` since it's a non-interactive element and it's missing a visual focus style anyway.

For toots with content warnings, having `tabindex="0"` may appear helpful since the content warning will get read by screen readers. However, this can be handled in another way:

1. Remove `tabindex="0"` from `.status__content`.
2. Give the content warning text wrapper (`<span class="translate" lang="">`) an `id` attribute
3. Give the content warning toggle button (`.status__content__spoiler-link`) an `aria-describedby` attribute and refer to the `id`.
4. The content warning will get read by screen readers when focussing the toggle button.

* Mastodon 4.0.0rc1
* Safari 16.1
* macOS 13.0
* VoiceOver

When a user requests follow recommendations, configured matching FASP are queried in the background.

prs.pr_body:
Follows up on https://github.com/mastodon/mastodon/pull/35025 and the other ones which explicitly removed the previous `ngrok` hostname value from specs.

One edge case I hadn't contemplated until I actually tried to remove that value or set it to something else ... there's subtle/different treatment of hostname-only vs hostname-plus-port here. With the default value of `localhost:3000` being used as the `LOCAL_DOMAIN` (set in 1_hosts initializer if no env var), some assertions which previously passed with the ngrok value (no port) now fail with that new value.

This is basically a once over for the failing spots where we **should have been** comparing just the host value but were getting away with the full compare due to how that value was set.

Main thing here is introduction of new spec helper method into an existing support file which lets us wrap up the "parse and pull out the host without port from the local domain" idea, and then updates to use that where relevant.

Small readability refactor in remote follow spec, and edge case handling in published scheduled announcement worker spec (twitter text regex needs a "real domain" to match in `Status.from_text`, so fails on `localhost`)

commit.commit_title: Fix vite helpers crash in development mode (#35035)

prs.pr_title: Fix vite helpers crash in development mode
prs.pr_body:
Fixes a regression from #35007

In that PR, we decided to load theme entrypoints by their name rather than file path, but to do so, we have relied on information that is only available when building the assets, while files are requested individually when `vite`'s dev server is used.

To fix this issue, this PR adds code to the `MastodonThemes` plugin to resolve requested themes on the fly. This is a bit of duplicate work, but the logic is kept in a single file.

This also changes the requested theme files to include `.css` (which is stripped when performing lookup). This is because the Vite dev server relies on the requested file's extension (in addition to the `Accept` header) to decide the `Content-Type` of the HTTP response.
